# Normalize

> Return a normal number `y` and exponent `exp` satisfying `x = y * 2^exp`.

<section class="usage">

## Usage

```javascript
var normalizef = require( '@stdlib/number/float32/base/normalize' );
```

#### normalizef( x )

Returns a normal number `y` and exponent `exp` satisfying `x = y * 2^exp`.

```javascript
var toFloat32 = require( '@stdlib/number/float64/base/to-float32' );

var out = normalizef( toFloat32( 1.401e-45 ) );
// returns [ 1.1754943508222875e-38, -23 ]
```

The first element of the returned `array` corresponds to `y` and the second to `exp`.

```javascript
var pow = require( '@stdlib/math/base/special/pow' );

var y = out[ 0 ];
var exp = out[ 1 ];

var bool = ( y*pow(2, exp) === toFloat32(1.401e-45) );
// returns true
```

The function expects a finite, non-zero [single-precision floating-point number][ieee754] `x`. If `x == 0`,

```javascript
var out = normalizef( 0.0 );
// returns [ 0.0, 0 ];
```

If `x` is either positive or negative `infinity` or `NaN`,

```javascript
var PINF = require( '@stdlib/math/constants/float32-pinf' );
var NINF = require( '@stdlib/math/constants/float32-ninf' );

var out = normalizef( PINF );
// returns [ PINF, 0 ]

out = normalizef( NINF );
// returns [ NINF, 0 ]

out = normalizef( NaN );
// returns [ NaN, 0 ]
```

</section>

<!-- /.usage -->

<section class="notes">

## Notes

-   While the function accepts higher precision [floating-point numbers][ieee754], beware that providing such numbers can be a source of subtle bugs as the relation `x = y * 2^exp` may **not** hold.

</section>

<!-- /.notes -->

<section class="examples">

## Examples

```javascript
var randu = require( '@stdlib/random/base/randu' );
var round = require( '@stdlib/math/base/special/round' );
var pow = require( '@stdlib/math/base/special/pow' );
var toFloat32 = require( '@stdlib/number/float64/base/to-float32' );
var normalizef = require( '@stdlib/number/float32/base/normalize' );

var frac;
var exp;
var x;
var v;
var i;

// Generate denormalized single-precision floating-point numbers and then normalize them...
for ( i = 0; i < 100; i++ ) {
    frac = randu() * 10.0;
    exp = 38 + round( randu()*6.0 );
    x = frac * pow( 10.0, -exp );
    x = toFloat32( x );
    v = normalizef( x );
    console.log( '%d = %d * 2^%d = %d', x, v[0], v[1], v[0]*pow(2.0, v[1]) );
}
```

</section>

<!-- /.examples -->

<section class="links">

[ieee754]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_754-1985

</section>

<!-- /.links -->
